Global governance should center on outcomes like development, rather than on democracy promotion. In many countries, democracy and democratization are the problems of governance, not solutions. Governance is the end, and democracy is merely a means to that end.

At the G20 summit on November 15, Chinese President Xi Jinping reiterated his call for a global development initiative and a global security initiative. China has shouldered more than its share of responsibility and demonstrated strong leadership.

As the international community struggles to address global challenges, there is an urgent need for global leadership from the two global powers. Power entails responsibility and leadership, and the two should work together to fulfill responsibilities and exercise leadership.

A fraught China-U.S. relationship leads to a deficit in global governance, Xie Tao, Dean of the School of International Relations and Diplomacy at Beijing Foreign Studies University, said on November 22 during a webinar on China-U.S. relations hosted by @BeijingReview. https://t.co/6c0spy8uvJ

"The U.S. believes China's rise may change the world order and undermine its interests. However, China's development is to benefit its people, rather than challenge other countries. If the misjudgment cannot be eliminated, the bilateral relations will not be stable."
"A healthy China-U.S. relationship depends on whether the strategic misjudgment by the U.S. regarding China can be eliminated," Xu added.

"The Xi-Biden meeting offers a crucial opportunity to put a floor beneath the China-U.S. relationship, but it's not enough," Xu Bu, President of the China Institute of International Studies, said on Nov 22 during a webinar on China-U.S. relations hosted by @BeijingReview. https://t.co/9Vejfgs4KG
